awd_abstract_narration:
This award is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems.

The Engineering Biology Research Consortium, or EBRC, aims to be the leading organization bringing together an inclusive community committed to advancing synthetic biology to address national and global needs. Synthetic biology encompasses an important set of tools and technologies to continue to build and strengthen the national bio-economy. EBRC supports and promotes the vision and goals of the United State synthetic biology community by providing the future vision for synthetic biology, bringing together industrial and research communities, catalyzing leading-edge research and education programs. In addition, EBRC is establishing training resources for synthetic biologists, and promoting and engaging in dialogue about synthetic biology among policy makers and other members of the public.

This project supports the development of a national-scale research roadmap for the field of synthetic biology in the United States to ensure the nation's continued international leadership in this critical area. Working with a diverse group of leading academic and industrial scientists from across the country, EBRC is developing and publishing a roadmap for the continued advancement of the field of engineering biology, with a focus on technical developments over the next decade. The project also addresses non-technical needs such as education and training, that are required to continue to advance the scientific field  and ensure the nation's leadership.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Engineering Biology Research Consortium (EBRC) brings together an inclusive community from academia, government, and industry to advance engineering biology to address national and global needs. Engineering biology is the focal point of a convergence of disciplines to enable technological innovation, economic growth, and scientific discovery, and EBRC brings the field together to achieve solutions to our most critical challenges, including crises in climate, food & water, energy, and health. Through EBRC's efforts under this award, experts work together to chart pathways to technical progress and breakthroughs, while actively incorporating policy, education, ethics, equity, and security considerations. EBRC works to accelerate innovation and grow a bioeconomy that benefits all.

EBRC has organized, developed, and executed its work across four Focus Areas (below); these are led by Working Groups comprised of EBRC academic and industry members. 

Technical Research Roadmapping 

Between 2019 and 2022, EBRC created and published five ambitious technical research roadmaps for the engineering biology community that lay out a vision for foundational research over the next two decades. It highlighted applications of engineering biology that may be possible in the short-, medium-, and long-term and research milestones that will enable us to get there. Four of these roadmaps were also developed as interactive versions on EBRC's website. 

Supported:

  • Engineering Biology: A Research Roadmap for the Next-Generation Bioeconomy (2019); also supported by NSF 1617030. 
    • An Assessment of the 2-year milestones outlined in the 2019 roadmap was initiated and developed under this funding; also supported by NSF 2116166. 
  • Microbiome Engineering: A Research Roadmap for the Next-Generation Bioeconomy (2020) examines technical progress needed to advance microbiome engineering and details how these advances can be used to develop engineered microbiomes for specific applications.
    • Its release was accompanied by "Engineering Microbiomes -Looking Ahead", published in ACS Synthetic Biology v.9, 2020.
  • Engineering Biology for Climate & Sustainability: A Research Roadmap for a Cleaner Future (2022), also supported by NSF 2116166.

Enabled (not funded under this award, but enabled by EBRC's core operations):

  • Enabling Defense Applications through Engineering Biology: A Technical Roadmap (2020), funded by the United States Air Force under Contract No. FA8650-15-D-5405.
  • Engineering Biology & Materials Science: A Research Roadmap for Interdisciplinary Innovation (2021), funded by NSF 2016758.

Education & Engagement

EBRC is committed to the education, training, and professional development of the next generation of engineering biology practitioners. It works to build standards and norms within the field for responsible and ethical conduct of research and to support diverse cohorts of trainees as they become the leaders of tomorrow. Through this award EBRC:

  • developed and grew the EBRC Industry Internship Program, which placed >20 graduate students in summer internships. This enabled them to gain valuable mentorship from outside academia, build professional connections, and experience research in industry. 
  • developed educational tools such as curriculum modules and publicly available resources through EBRSee (see "YouTube resources for synthetic biology education" in Synthetic Biology v.4 , 2019). 
  • established and fostered the ~235 member EBRC Student and Postdoc Association, which serves as a space for trainee community-building, professional development, and mentorship.
  • established the EBRC Science Policy Postdoc program, providing mentorship and career development to four fellows with this award.

Policy & International Engagement

EBRC has established a network of hundreds of experts and leaders, which can be rapidly mobilized to serve as a resource to government and industry, in support of U.S. leadership toward an equitable, sustainable bioeconomy. EBRC has actively engaged on public policy issues that affect or are affected by the advancement of engineering biology. Internationally, EBRC serves as a focal point for engagement, representing the U.S. engineering biology research community in key international forums and processes. 

  • EBRC provided requested information to policymakers and U.S. government officials, sharing expertise and insight from the research base. 
  • EBRC planned the first EBRC Global Forum in 2019, which brought together delegates from around the world, to share national bioeconomy strategies, facilitating international cooperation and progress.

Security

Many tools and technologies that enable innovative biology-based approaches to societal problems could also be used in ways that cause harm to people or the planet. EBRC brings stakeholders together to understand the nature of these potential negative outcomes and build strategies to minimize and mitigate them. Members of the Security Working Group developed and published:

  • "Guiding Ethical Principles in Engineering Biology Research," ACS Synthetic Biology, v.10, 2021.
  • "Making Security Viral: Shifting Engineering Biology Culture and Publishing", ACS Synthetic Biology, v.11, 2022.

Through its activities, EBRC Annual Meetings, and Council retreats, EBRC has brought the field together and maintained connection during the COVID-19 pandemic. By building an active community able to identify common challenges and opportunities across academia, industry, and government, EBRC was and is well prepared to respond and lead in the modern bioeconomy.
